Example

Use the convolution theorem to find the inverse transform of \(\displaystyle{H(s)={s\over {(s-1)(s^2+1)}}}\).

Solution

Begin by choosing two functions of \(s\), that is, \(F(s)\) and \(G(s)\):

Although there are many possibilities it would seem sensible to choose \[ F(s)={{1\over {s-1}}}\qquad \text{and} \qquad G(s)={{s\over {s^2+1}}}\] since, by inspection, we can write down their inverse Laplace transforms: \[\qquad\displaystyle f(t)={\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)\}=\text{e}^tu(t)\qquad\text{ and}\qquad g(t)={\cal L}^{-1}\{G(s)\}=\cos t.u(t)\]

Now construct the convolution integral:

\[\begin{eqnarray*} h(t)&=&{\cal L}^{-1}\{H(s)\}\\&=&{\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)G(s)\}\\&=&\int_0^tf(t-x)g(x)\,dx=\int_0^t\text{e}^{t-x}u(t-x)\cos x.u(x)\,dx\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*}\]

Now complete the evaluation of the integral, treating the cases \(t<0\) and \(t\ge 0\) separately:

You should find \(h(t)={1\over 2}(\sin t-\cos t +\text{e}^t)u(t)\) since \(h(t)=0\) if \(t<0\) and \[\begin{eqnarray*} h(t)&=&\int_0^t\text{e}^{t-x}\cos x\,dx\qquad \text{ if}\quad t\ge 0\\&=&\biggl[\text{e}^{t-x}\sin x\biggr]_0^t-\int_0^t(-1)\text{e}^{t-x}\sin x\,dx\qquad \text{(integrating by parts)}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \\ &=&\sin t+\biggl[- \text{e}^{t-x}\cos x \biggr]_0^t-\int_0^t(-\text{e}^{t-x})(-\cos x)\,dx\\&=&\sin t-\cos t +\text{e}^t-h(t)\\\text{ or}\qquad 2h(t)&=&\sin t-\cos t+\text{e}^t\qquad t\ge 0 \end{eqnarray*}\] Finally \(h(t)={1\over 2}(\sin t-\cos t+\text{e}^t)u(t)\).
